(c) in a case where the debtor carries on a business or intends,

when circumstances permit, to resume the carrying on of a business suspended owing to war circumstances—

(i) for excepting from the property to be realised the business, any premises used for the business, and such other property as in the opinion of the court is required for the purposes of the business;

(ii) for securing the repayment of, or the payment of interest on, any sums borrowed by the debtor with the consent of the court for the purposes of the business; and

(iii) for postponing the payment of the debts or any of them for such period as the court thinks fit;

so, however, that in exercising the powers aforesaid the court shall have regard to the prospects of the business and the likelihood of ultimate benefit to the creditors as well as to the debtor;

(d) in the case of any property which in the opinion of the'

court it would be unreasonable to realise immediately owing to its temporary depreciation in value or for any other sufficient cause, for postponing realisation for such period as the court thinks fit.

5. — (1) The court may provide in a liabilities adjustment order for the disclaimer of any such leases, contracts or other property as could, if the debtor were bankrupt, be disclaimed in bankruptcy, and any person injured as the result of any such disclaimer shall be deemed to be a creditor of the debtor to the extent of his injury and may accordingly prove therefor.

7. — (1) Any mortgagee—

(a) may, if he is entitled and permitted by the court to do

so, realise his security, and, if the sum realised is less than the amount secured, may prove for the balance;

(b) if he does not realise his security, may surrender it and

prove for the whole amount secured;

(c) if he does not realise or surrender his security, may

cause it to be valued and, if the value is less than the amount secured, may prove for the balance.

(2) Where a security is valued and the value is less than the amount secured, the security shall be deemed only to secure a debt of that value, and the instrument creating the mortgage shall have effect accordingly:

Provided that the court may allow the valuation to be amended at any time during which the security is not permitted to be realised, and, if the security is realised, the value thereof shall be deemed to be the net amount realised, and such adjustments as may be necessary with respect to any amounts paid or to be paid by way of dividend in respect of any balance of the debt for which the creditor has proved shall be made in accordance with rules made under this Part of this Act, but any liability for interest in respect of any period prior to the amendment of the valuation, or the realisation, of the security shall not be affected.

(3) If and so long as any mortgagee is not permitted to realise his security and does not surrender his security, the

debtor shall, subject to the last foregoing subsection and the following provisions of this subsection, remain personally liable to pay interest and to repay the amount secured by the mortgage in accordance with the instrument creating the mortgage:

Provided that the court may direct in the liabilities adjustment order that—

(a) interest in respect of the period for which the order is in force or any less period shall be payable at such reduced rate as may be specified in the order;

(b) during the period for which the order is in force or any

less period no payments shall be made in respect of the amount secured by the mortgage or payments shall only be made in such manner and at such times as may be specified in the order; and the instrument creating the mortgage shall have effect subject to the provisions of the order.

(4) The court shall not reduce the rate of interest under the last foregoing subsection, unless the annual amount payable by way of interest at the existing rate exceeds the net annual value of the mortgaged property at the date of the order and any such reduction of the rate of interest shall be limited to the extent of that excess.

(5) Where, in the case of any mortgaged property of the debtor, the amount secured, together with interest thereon, is repayable by instalments, the court may direct that any provision in the instrument creating the mortgage to the effect that, on a default in the payment of any such instalment, the whole amount of that and of any future instalments shall immediately become due and charged on the property, shall not have effect in so far as it relates to so much of those future instalments as consists of interest.

(6) Where the instrument creating any mortgage is varied by or under this section, the court may make such consequential amendments and adjustments of that instrument as it considers necessary.

8. — (1) Where the court exercises its powers so as to allow the debtor to remain in possession of any property, or postpones the realisation of any property, it shall make provision in the liabilities adjustment order for securing the payment of any sums payable by the debtor in respect of the property after the date of the protection order, subject to any variation of any lease, contract or mortgage affecting the property made by or under this Part of this Act, and in particular for securing—

(a) the payment of rent, rates and taxes;

(b) the payment of mortgage interest and any sums payable

in respect of the amount secured by a mortgage;

(c) in a case where the property is an insurance policy,

the payment of premiums on the policy.

(2) Where the court provides for the vesting in the debtor of any goods let under a hire-purchase agreement after the payment of such sums as may be specified in the liabilities adjustment order, the order shall make provision for securing the payment of those sums.

(3) Where the debtor remains bound by a contract entered into before the date of the protection order, the court shall make provision in the liabilities adjustment order for securing the performance by the debtor of his obligations under the contract, subject to any variation of the contract made by the court.

(4) Without prejudice to the power of the court to give directions as to the management and disposal of the debtor’s property, where any lease, mortgage or contract is varied by or under any provision of this Part of this Act, the interest of the debtor in the lease or contract or, as the case may be, in the mortgaged property shall not be assignable by him except with the consent of the court and upon such conditions as it may impose.

9. — (1) Subject to the provisions of this section, a liabilities adjustment order shall secure that any sums available from time to time for the satisfaction of the proved debts of the debtor shall be expended—

(a) first, in the payment of the debts which would

have been entitled to be paid in priority under subsection (1) of section thirty-three of the Bankruptcy Act, 1914, if a receiving order had been made against the debtor at the date of the protection order;

(b) secondly, after the payment in full of the debts mentioned

in the foregoing paragraph, in the payment of the other proved debts.

(2) Subject as hereinafter provided and to any rules made under this Part of this Act, all debts falling within either of the classes specified in the last foregoing subsection shall rank equally between themselves:

Provided that, if the liabilities adjustment order provides for the postponement of the realisation or distribution of a substantial part of the debtor’s property, and the court considers that, in the case of any debt or debts falling within paragraph (b) of the last foregoing subsection, delay in payment would cause exceptional hardship, the order may provide for the payment of that debt or those debts in priority to other debts falling within the said paragraph (b).

(3) Where it appears to the court that a debtor is in a position not only to pay the proved debts in full, but also interest thereon from the date of the protection order, the liabilities adjustment order may provide for the payment of such interest at such rate, not exceeding three per cent, per annum, as may be specified in the order.

(4) The payment of debts in accordance with this section shall be subject to any provision made by the court in the liabilities adjustment order—

10. — (1) The court may provide for the adjustment and settlement of a debtor's affairs by means of a single liabilities adjustment order, or, if that is not practicable, may make an interim order or interim orders providing for any of the matters for which provision may be made by a liabilities adjustment order, and accordingly references in this Part of this Act to a liabilities adjustment order shall include references to any such interim order.

(2) Any liabilities adjustment order or protection order may, on the application of the debtor or of any creditor whose debt has been proved or of the liabilities adjustment officer, be varied by a subsequent order, and, in particular, where a liabilities adjustment order reduces the rent of any premises or the rate of mortgage interest payable in respect of any mortgaged property, an application for the variation of the order may be made on the ground that the lettable value of the premises or, as the case may be, the net annual value of the mortgaged property has altered since the date of the order.

(3) Any creditor whose debt has been proved or the liabilities adjustment officer may apply to the court to revoke a liabilities adjustment order on the ground that—

(a) the debtor has failed to comply with the order;

(б) the debtor is guilty of any act or omission which would

constitute an offence under this Part of this Act, or has carried out any transaction which would be treated as a fraudulent preference in bankruptcy or would be void against the trustee in bankruptcy, or has in any other respect failed to act in complete good faith towards his creditors; or

(c) that the case, owing to its complexity or for any other reason, is not a practicable case to be dealt with under this Part of this Act;

and the court, if satisfied as to the ground alleged, may revoke the liabilities adjustment order and the protection order, and

11. — (1) The court may at any time refer to the liabilities adjustment officer any question arising in the course of liabilities adjustment proceedings for his investigation and report thereon.

(2) Where any reference is made to the liabilities adjustment officer under this section or under section three of this Act, the debtor shall give to that officer such information, produce to him such documents and attend such meetings, as he may reasonably require, and shall afford to him all possible assistance; and if the debtor wilfully fails to carry out his duties under this subsection, he shall be guilty of a contempt of court in like manner as if he disobeyed an order of the court and may be punished accordingly.

12. — (1) Where the debtor has paid, either in full or to such extent as the liabilities adjustment order may specify, the proved debts and any costs of the proceedings payable by him and has otherwise complied with the order, the court shall on his application make an order of discharge, and he shall thereupon, subject to the next following subsection, be released from all debts provable in the proceedings, except those from which a bankrupt would not, by virtue of section twenty-eight of the Bankruptcy Act, 1914, be released by an order of discharge under that Act, and the liabilities adjustment order and the protection order shall cease to have effect.

(2) Where, at the date of an application for an order of discharge, the debtor still retains possession by virtue of the exercise of the powers of the court of any property held on a lease or subject to a mortgage, or is still liable in respect of any loan or other contract the repayment or performance of which is provided for in the liabilities adjustment order, the court may nevertheless make an order of discharge and—

(a) may direct that the liabilities adjustment order and the protection order shall continue in force so far as relates to the lease, mortgage or contract;

14. — (1) Where the debtor is carrying on business in partnership Provisions as with others, and no application is made under subsection (5) of to partnership, this section in respect of the firm, the court may, if it considers that it is in the interest of the debtor and the creditors to do so, allow the debtor to remain a partner in the business, and exclude from the property to be realised under the liabilities adjustment order any of the debtor’s property which in the opinion of the court is required for the purposes of the business; and in that case the liabilities of the firm and any liabilities of the debtor arising out of the contract of partnership shall not be provable debts, and the court shall, in settling the terms of the liabilities adjustment order, have regard to the requirements of the debtor as a member of the firm.

(2) The powers of the court under the last foregoing subsection shall be subject to any term of the contract of partnership providing for the dissolution thereof or the vesting of the debtor's share in the other partners, but nothing done or suffered by the debtor under, or for the purpose of taking advantage of, any provision of this Part of this Act shall be a ground for an application to any court for dissolution of the partnership.

(3) If, in any case to which subsection (1) of this section applies, the court does not exercise its powers under that subsection, and the contract of partnership does not provide for the dissolution of the partnership or the vesting of the debtor’s share in the other partners, the court shall provide in the liabilities adjustment order for the dissolution and winding up of the partnership or for the vesting of the debtor’s share in the other partners, on such terms as seem just, and may give such directions as it considers necessary or expedient for that purpose.

(4) Whether or not the partnership is dissolved, the court may give to the debtor such directions as it thinks fit as to the exercise of his rights under the contract of partnership, or may appoint any person to exercise those rights on his behalf:

Provided that nothing in this subsection shall authorise any interference with the conduct of the partnership business or be taken as effecting the terms of the contract of partnership.

(5) Where any persons are carrying on business in partnership and—

(a) both the firm and all the partners are unable to pay their accrued debts or will be unable, after payment of their accrued debts (if any), to meet, as they fall due, any future liabilities in respect of obligations already incurred, or are in such a position that, if they were required to pay their accrued debts and to meet any

such future liabilities as they fell due, they would have no reasonable prospect of preserving or recovering the business of the firm or, in the case of the partners, would otherwise lose their means of livelihood; and

(6) the position of the firm is due to war circumstances;

an application may be made for the adjustment and settlement of the affairs of the firm under this Part of this Act, and any such application shall be taken as an application for the making of a separate liabilities adjustment order in relation to the firm and to each partner therein, and the references in subsection (1) of section three of this Act to the debtor shall be construed as references to the firm or any of the partners, and the references in that subsection and in section ten of this Act to creditors shall be construed as including references to creditors of the firm or of any of the partners.

(6) Where liabilities adjustment proceedings are brought in respect of a firm, the provisions of the Bankruptcy Act, 1914, relating to the manner in which the joint and separate debts and estates of partners are to be dealt with shall apply for the purposes of those proceedings, subject to such adaptations, modifications and exceptions as may be prescribed.

(7) Where the court does not exercise, in relation to a firm, its powers under this Part of this Act for the purpose of enabling the business of the firm to be carried on or resumed, it shall provide in the liabilities adjustment order for the dissolution and winding up of the partnership, and may give such directions as it considers necessary or expedient for that purpose.

(8) If on an application in respect of a firm it appears to the court that a liabilities adjustment order cannot or ought not to be made in relation to any partner, and that it is in the interest of the other partners that an order should be made in respect of the firm, the court may order that the share of that partner in the firm shall vest in the other partners on such terms as seem just, and this section shall have effect accordingly and, if there is only one other partner, the application shall be treated as an application in respect of that other partner in his own name.

(9) A scheme of arrangement with respect to the affairs of a firm may, with the assent of all the partners, be approved under this Part of this Act, but no scheme of arrangement with respect to the affairs of an individual partner in a firm shall, while the firm continues in existence and he remains a partner therein, deal with the liabilities of the firm or any liabilities of the partner arising out of the contract of partnership.

15. — (1) The provisions of this Part of this Act shall apply, subject to the provisions of this section, to private companies within the meaning of the Companies Act, 1929, but shall not apply to any other body corporate.

Adjustment) Act, 1941.

(2) An application shall not be made by a company for the adjustment and settlement of the company’s affairs under this Part of this Act unless a special resolution within the meaning of the Companies Act, 1929, has been passed by the company resolving that the application be made.

(3) No application for the adjustment and settlement of a company’s affairs under this Part of this Act shall be entertained unless the court is satisfied that the principal object of the company is to carry dn a business for profit, and that the object of the application is to enable the company to carry on or recover that business; and the court shall, in considering whether it is practicable and proper to deal with the affairs of a company under this Part of this Act, have regard to the constitution and history of the company and the means of the members and officers thereof.

(4) A liabilities adjustment order made in the case of the company may, in addition to any of the other matters mentioned in this Part of this Act, provide for the making of calls upon the contributories of the company.

(5) Rules made under this Part of this Act may make provision as to the manner in which any floating charge on the undertaking or property of a company is to operate in a case where liabilities adjustment proceedings are brought in respect of the affairs of the company, and may make such adaptations and modifications of, and such exceptions from, the provisions of this Part of this Act relating to mortgagees, in their application to the holders of debentures whose rights are secured by a floating charge, as may be necessary.

(6) In relation to a company, this Part of this Act shall have effect as if—

(a) the references to bankruptcy or bankruptcy proceedings

1914, were a reference to section two hundred and sixty-seven of the Companies Act, 1929;

(d) the references to a receiving order were references to an

order for the compulsory winding up of the company which had not previously commenced to be wound up voluntarily;

16. — (1) The Lord Chancellor may make general rules for carrying into effect the objects of this Part of this Act:

Provided that the said rules shall not extend the jurisdiction of the court.

(2) Without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing subsection, the rules—

(a) shall provide for the giving of notice of liabilities adjustment proceedings and of meetings held by liabilities adjustment officers, and of proposals for schemes of arrangement under this Part of this Act;

(б) shall provide for the proof of debts, both for the purposes

of any liabilities adjustment proceedings and for the purposes of any scheme of arrangement under this Part of this Act, and may allow any creditor whose debt is overdue at the date of the protection order or, as the case may be, at the date of the approval of the scheme, to prove for interest up to the said date at the rate agreed or, if no rate has been agreed, at such rate not exceeding three per cent, per annum as may be prescribed;

(c) shall prescribe the method of valuing securities, debts and liabilities, and in particular future and contingent liabilities;

(d) may prescribe the fees to be paid in respect of the services

of liabilities adjustment officers;

(e) may apply, subject to such adaptations, modifications

and exceptions as may be necessary, any provisions of the Bankruptcy Act, 1914, relating to the proof of debts, mutual credit or set off, execution and attachment, the postponement of husbands' or wives’ claims and claims under covenants and contracts made

1941- Liabilities (War-Time Ch. 24.

Adjustment) Act, 1941.

in consideration of marriage, and, in relation to a company, any corresponding provisions of Part V of the Companies Act, 1929, and the provisions of paragraph (5) of subsection (4) of section two hundred and sixty-four of that Act, and may also apply, subject as aforesaid, section three of the Partnership Act, 1890.

(3) Rules made under this section shall as soon as may be after they are made be laid before Parliament, but section one of the Rules Publication Act, 1893, shall not apply to rules so made.

17. — (1) Subject to the provisions of this Part of this Act relating to partnership, all debts and liabilities of the debtor which would be provable in bankruptcy if a receiving order had been made at the material date shall be provable debts for the purposes of this Part of this Act, together with any other liabilities included as provable debts by any provision of or rule made under this Part of this Act; and the expression “ provable debt ” shall be construed accordingly.

(2) For the purposes of the last foregoing subsection,the material date

(a) in relation to any liabilities adjustment proceedings,

shall be the date of the protection order;

(b) in relation to any scheme of arrangement, or negotiations

for such a scheme, shall be such date as may be notified by the liabilities adjustment officer in the prescribed manner.

(3) Nothing in Regulation four of the Defence (Evacuated Areas) Regulations, 1940, shall be taken to prevent any of the sums mentioned in that Regulation being dealt with in a liabilities adjustment order or scheme of arrangement approved under this Part of this Act, and being proved and discharged in liabilities adjustment proceedings or under any such scheme.

18. — (1) Where a liabilities adjustment order varies under section six or section seven of this Act the terms of any lease or mortgage, the liabilities of any other person under that lease or mortgage, whether as a person jointly bound with the debtor, or as a surety for him, shall be correspondingly varied.

(2) Save as aforesaid, the making of a liabilities adjustment order or the approving of a scheme of arrangement under this Part of this Act shall not affect the liabilities of any person who is a surety or in the nature of a surety for the debtor or is jointly bound with him, nor shall an order of discharge release any such person from those liabilities.

19. If any debtor—

(a) knowingly makes any false statement, or omits to state

any material fact, for the purpose of securing the assent of the creditors to a scheme of arrangement under this Part of this Act or the exercise in favour of the debtor of any power of the court or of a liabilities adjustment officer under this Part of this Act; or

(б) after the approval of a scheme of arrangement or the

making of a protection order under this Part of this Act in relation to the debtor, fraudulently conceals, removes or disposes of any part of the debtor's property;

he shall be liable, on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years, or, on summary conviction, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding three months.

20. — (1) Subject to the provisions of section one hundred and eleven of the County Courts Act, 1934 (which provides for the removal into the High Court of any proceedings commenced in a county court), the jurisdiction of the court under this Part of this Act shall be exercised by a county court:

Provided that, in a case where the debtor is a company, the said jurisdiction shall be exercised by such court or courts as would have jurisdiction to wind up the company.

(2) The court shall have full power to decide all questions whatsoever, whether of law or fact, which may arise in the course of any liabilities adjustment proceedings and which the court may deem it expedient or necessary to decide for the purpose of making or varying the liabilities adjustment order.

(3) Any court before which are pending any proceedings in respect of a debt or liability which would be a debt provable in liabilities adjustment proceedings, may stay the proceedings—

(a) on the ground that the debtor or defendant is availing

himself of the services of a liabilities adjustment officer with a view to arriving at a scheme of arrangement with his creditors; or

(b) for the purpose of enabling the debtor or defendant to

avail himself of the services of a liabilities adjustment officer or to make an application to the court for the adjustment and settlement of his affairs under this Part of this Act.

(4) When any proceedings pending in the High Court are stayed by virtue of a protection order, the High Court may direct that the proceedings shall be transferred to the court which made the order.

21. — (1) Nothing done or suffered by any person under, or for the purpose of taking advantage of, any provisions of this

1941.

Adjustment) Act, 1941.

189

Part of this Act shall be deemed to be an act of bankruptcy, and nothing so done or suffered shall disqualify any person from any office for which he would be disqualified under any enactment (including an enactment in a local Act) by bankruptcy or by entering into any composition or arrangement with his creditors.

(2) Where any protection order or scheme of arrangement is revoked under this Part of this Act, the period between the making of the protection order or, as the case may be, the approving of the scheme of arrangement, and the revocation of the order or scheme shall, for the purposes of the Bankruptcy Act, 1914, Part V of the Companies Act, 1929, any enactment relating to the limitation of actions and any other enactment whereby any liability of the debtor may be affected by the passage of time, be disregarded.

22. Where a protection order is made, or a scheme of arrangement is approved, under this Part of this Act—

(a) every deed, conveyance, assignment or other instrument relating solely to property which was the property of the debtor at the date of the protection order or of the approval of the scheme and which, after the execution of the instrument, is or remains his property or the property of a trustee appointed under the order or for the purposes of the scheme;

(b) every power of attorney, proxy paper, writ, order,

certificate, affidavit, bond or other instrument required for the purposes of the liabilities adjustment proceedings or the scheme of arrangement;

shall be exempt from stamp duties, except in respect of fees chargeable under this Act.

23. This Part of this Act shall, subject to any exceptions or modifications provided for therein, apply in relation to debts and liabilities due to or incurred towards the Crown, property in which the Crown has an interest, leases, mortgages and contracts entered into with the Crown, proceedings by the Crown, and the exercise of remedies by the Crown, in like manner as in the case of subjects:

Provided that nothing in this section shall be taken as affecting the prosecution of any criminal proceedings.

24. — (1) This Part of this Act shall only apply in a case where, at the date when liabilities adjustment proceedings are commenced, or, as the case may be, the services of a liabilities adjustment officer are sought, the debtor—

(a) if an individual, ordinarily resides in England, or carries

on business in England, or is a member of a firm which carries on business in England; or

(b) if a firm or a company, carries on business in England.

For the purposes of this subsection—

(i) where the principal place of business of the debtor (whether

an individual, firm or company) is in Scotland or Northern Ireland, the debtor shall not be deemed to be carrying on business in England;

(ii) any debtor who, by reason only of war circumstances, ceased ordinarily to reside in England before the said date, or suspended the carrying on of a business previously carried on in England, shall be deemed still ordinarily to reside, or* as the case may be, to carry on business, in England at the said date.

(2) This Part of this Act shall apply to any property of a debtor, whether situated in England or elsewhere, and to any contracts, debts and liabilities of a debtor, whether made or incurred in England or elsewhere:

Provided that the powers conferred on a court by section six and section seven of this Act to vary the terms of leases, mortgages and other contracts shall only be exercised in relation to property in England and contracts governed by the law of England.

(3) A scheme of arrangement approved under this Part of this Act, and any protection order, liabilities adjustment order and order of discharge made under this Part of this Act, and anything done in pursuance of any such scheme or order, shall be as valid and effective in Scotland, Northern Ireland and the Isle of Man as it is in England; and the power exercisable by any court under section twenty of this Act to stay proceedings shall be exercisable by courts in Scotland, Northern Ireland and the Isle of Man and shall have effect, in relation to Scottish courts, as if for the expression “ stay ” there were substituted the expression " sist”.

(4) Any reference to section one of the Courts (Emergency Powers) Act, 1939, and to subsection (5) of that section shall respectively include a reference to section one of the Courts (Emergency Powers) (Scotland) Act, 1939, and to subsection (4) of that section and any reference to a bankruptcy petition shall include a reference to a petition for sequestration.

(5) Any reference in this Part of this Act to any Regulation of the Defence (Evacuated Areas) Regulations, 1940, shall include a reference to that Regulation as extended to Northern Ireland.

(6) Subject to the provisions of this section, this Part of this Act shall only extend to England.

25. Notwithstanding anything in the Government of Ireland Act, 1920, the Parliament of Northern Ireland shall have power to make laws, in relation to persons ordinarily resident or carrying on business in Northern Ireland, for purposes similar to the purposes of this Part of this Act.

Part II.

Extension of certain Enactments to Contracts made after Commencement of War.

26. — (1) Where any judgment or order has been given or made by any court, whether before or after the passing of this Act,—

(a) for the recovery of a debt which has become due by virtue of a contract made after the commencement of the principal Act; or

(b) for the recovery of possession of land in default of payment of rent, or for the recovery of possession of land other than a dwelling-house by a mortgagee thereof by reason of a default in the payment of money, being land held on a lease or tenancy, or subject to a mortgage, entered into after the commencement of the principal Act: or

Extension of Courts (Emergency Powers) Acts, 1939 and 1940, to contracts made after the commencement of war.

(c) for the delivery of any property other than land by reason of a default under any contract made after the commencement of the principal Act in the payment of money;

then, if the defendant satisfies the appropriate court that he is unable immediately to satisfy the judgment or order, or to pay the rent or money, by reason of circumstances directly or indirectly attributable to any war in which His Majesty may be engaged, being circumstances which arose after the contract, lease, tenancy or mortgage was made or entered into, the appropriate court may direct that the principal Act shall have effect as if the contract, lease, tenancy or mortgage had been made or entered into before the commencement of that Act, and the powers of the court shall thereupon be exercisable as if an application for leave to execute the judgment or order had been made under that Act.

Part III.

Interpretation, Title and Operation.

28. — (1) In this Act unless the context otherwise requires Interpretation, the following expressions have the meanings hereby respectively assigned to them :—

“ business ” includes trade or profession, and also includes, as the context may require, the goodwill acquired by a person engaged in a trade or profession;

" the court” means a court exercising jurisdiction under Part I of this Act;

“ the debtor ” means, in relation to any scheme of arrangement or liabilities adjustment proceedings, the person to whose affairs the scheme or proceedings relate;

" hire-purchase agreement” means any agreement defined as a hire-purchase agreement by section twenty-one of the Hire Purchase Act, 1938, and also includes Geo. 6. any agreement for the sale of goods under which the c- 53-price is payable by instalments and the property in the goods remains in the seller, notwithstanding that the buyer is in possession of the goods, until such conditions as to the payment of instalments or otherwise as may be specified in the agreement are fulfilled; and any reference, in relation to a debtor, to goods let under a hire-purchase agreement shall be construed as meaning any goods delivered to the debtor under a hire-purchase agreement and in his possession, being goods the property in which remains in the seller or letter thereof;

“ hire-purchase price” means the total sum payable by the hirer or buyer under a hire-purchase agreement in order to complete the purchase of goods to which the agreement relates, exclusive of any sum payable as a penalty or as compensation or damages for a breach of the agreement;

“ lettable value ” means, in relation to any premises, the rent at which, in the opinion of the court, the premises might reasonably be expected to let from year to year upon the same terms and conditions (other than the period of the lease or tenancy) as those of the existing lease or tenancy, or, in the case of premises which the tenant is holding over, upon the same terms and conditions as those upon which he is holding over the premises;

“ liabilities adjustment proceedings” means proceedings for the adjustment and settlement of a debtor’s affairs under Part I of this Act;

CHAPTER 25.

An Act to enable rating authorities in Scotland to grant relief from rates in respect of lands and heritages suffering war damage.

[12th June 1941.]

BE it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows :—

1. Where a rating authority in Scotland are satisfied that any lands and heritages in their area have, whether before or after the passing of this Act, become, by the occurrence of war damage thereto, wholly or to a substantial extent incapable of beneficial occupation, the authority may grant to any person relief from such proportion of the rates in respect of the lands and heritages

1941. Rating ( War Damage) Ch. 25,26. 195

(Scotland) Act, 1941.

as they, having regard to the extent to which and the period during which those lands and heritages have been or are likely to be so incapable, may think just and equitable, and may grant such relief either by reduction of assessment or by repayment of rates already paid.

2. — (1) In this Act the expression “ rating authority” means a Interpretation county or a town council or other body empowered by any and citation, enactment to levy a rate; and the expression " war damage ” has the like meaning as in the War Damage Act, 1941. 4 & 5 Geo. 6.

(2) This Act may be cited as the Rating (War Damage) (Scot- c* I2* land) Act, 1941.

CHAPTER 27.

An Act to provide for the establishment of supplemental lists of justices of the peace and for limiting the powers and duties of justices whose names are entered in such lists.

[2nd July 1941.]

BE it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows:—

1. — (1) The Lord Chancellor may make rules directing that in connection with any commission of the peace issued by His Majesty there shall be kept a list to be called “ the supplemental list”, and those rules shall make provision for the entry in such lists of the names of justices who apply to have their names entered therein, and for the removal of names from such lists. 2 *

(2) A justice of the peace whose name is for the time being entered in the supplemental list kept in connection with any commission of the peace shall not be qualified to sit as a member of any court of quarter sessions or court of summary jurisdiction or as a licensing justice or as a member of any confirming authority or compensation authority under the Licensing (Consolidation) Act, 1910:

Provided that a justice whose name is so entered shall not be disqualified from taking part in any business of a court of

1941.

Justices (Supplemental List) Act, 1941.

Ch. 27.

197

quarter sessions relating oiily to the appointment of committees or other like administrative matters, or from sitting as a member of such a court while such business is being transacted.

(3) If the Lord Chancellor is satisfied, with respect to any justice named in a commission of the peace, that it is, by reason of his age or infirmity or other like cause, expedient that he should cease to exercise judicial functions, the Lord Chancellor may direct that the name of that justice shall be entered in the supplemental list kept in connection with that commission of the peace.

(4) The rules made under this Act may provide that if, with respect to any commission of the peace, it appears to the Lord Chancellor that those of the justices named therein who are to be subject to the disqualifications specified in subsection (2) of this section can be more conveniently designated in some manner other than the entry of their names in the supplemental list, they may be designated in such other manner as may be prescribed by the rules, and, where such provision is made, the rules shall provide for the application of this Act, with the necessary adaptations, to the designation of such justices, and to justices so designated, in like manner in all respects as it applies to the entry of the names of justices in supplemental lists, and to justices whose names are entered in such lists.

(5) In this Act—

(a) the expression “ court of quarter sessions ” includes any committee by which the powers and duties of such a court are exercisable by virtue of any Act; and

(b) the expression “ court of summary jurisdiction ” means

a court consisting of any justice or justices of the peace sitting in his or their capacity as such, not being a court of quarter sessions.

CHAPTER 28.

An Act to remove doubts as to, and to supplement, the powers of trustees in relation to insurance against war damage.

[2nd July 1941.]

BE it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows :—

1. Whereas doubts have arisen in the case of trustees holding upon trusts the execution of which is governed by the law of England or of Northern Ireland, as to their powers in relation to insurance under Part II of the War Damage Act, 1941, and it is expedient to remove the doubts as to, and to supplement, the said powers:

Now therefore:—

(1) A trustee shall have power, and shall be deemed at all material times to have had power, if and in so far as a contrary intention is not expressed in the instrument, if any, creating the trust and subject to the terms of that instrument—

(a) to effect any insurance which the Board of Trade are authorised to undertake under either of the schemes operated under Part II of the War Damage Act, 1941, up to the full value of the goods insured; and

(b) for the purpose of paying the premiums for such insurance in accordance with section eighty-two of the said Act, to apply any capital money or securities subject to the same trusts as those affecting the goods insured, and, pending the making of provision for such application as aforesaid, to apply the income of any property subject to those trusts, without obtaining the consent of any person entitled wholly or partly to such money, securities or property or to the income thereof.

(2) Nothing in the preceding subsection shall be taken to prejudice or affect the power conferred on the Board of Trade by section sixty-seven of the War Damage Act, 1941, to refuse an application for the issue of a policy, or any power vested in a trustee by the instrument, if any, creating the trust or by law to effect an insurance against war damage otherwise than under the said schemes or against a risk other than war damage. 3

(3) In this Act the expressions “ trust”, “ trustee ”," instrument”, and “securities”, have the meanings assigned to them respectively by the Trustee Act, 1925.

1941.

(War Damage Insurance) Act, 1941.

(4) In the application of this Act to Northern Ireland, for the reference to the Trustee Act, 1925, there shall be substituted a reference to the Trustee Act, 1893.

2. This Act may be cited as the Trustee (War Damage Insurance) Act, 1941.

the amount ascertained and recorded under the said subsection (1) in relation to that man for that year shall, instead of being credited wholly to him, be credited partly to him and partly to her, in such proportions as may be agreed between them, or as may, in default of agreement, be determined by—

(i) ascertaining what the said amount would have been if, in the said subsection (1), for the references to subsections (2), (3) and (4) of the last preceding section,

1941.

Finance Act, 1941.

205

Ch. 30.

there had been substituted references to so much of the said subsection (2^ as amends subsection (1) of section fifteen of the Finance Act, 1925; and

(ii) apportioning that part of the amount between them in proportion to their respective earned incomes for the said year; and

(iii) apportioning the remainder of the amount between them in proportion to their respective total incomes for the said year, reduced, if relief has been given for that year under subsection (1) of the said section fifteen, by the appropriate sum in respect of earned income relief.

In this subsection, the expression “ the appropriate sum in respect of earned income relief " means, in relation to a man or his wife, a sum equal to one-tenth of his or her earned income for the year in question, or, if their combined earned incomes for the year exceed fifteen hundred pounds, a sum which bears to a hundred and fifty pounds the same proportion that his or her earned income for the year bears to their combined earned incomes for the year.

(3) The procedure for the ascertainment and recording of the amounts to be ascertained and recorded under subsection

(1) of this section and for the determination of the matters to be determined under subsection (2) of this section shall be such as may be prescribed by regulations made by the Commissioners of Inland Revenue, and those regulations shall provide for the giving of notice to the persons affected and for appeals, and, without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing words, the regulations may apply any of the enactments relating to appeals from assessments to income tax.

(4) Any assignment of or charge on any amount to be credited under this section, and any agreement for any such assignment or charge, shall be void, and any such amount shall be exempt from death duties payable on any death occurring before the date fixed by the Treasury under subsection (1) of this section; but any claim to any such amount shall, subject as aforesaid, be transmissible as if it were a debt due from the Crown, and refeiences in the foregoing provisions of this section to an individual, a man or his wife shall, except where the context otherwise requires, be deemed to include references to persons claiming through or under them respectively:

Provided that nothing in this subsection shall affect any assignment or charge made by the personal representatives of any person acting in their capacity as such, or any agreement for any such assignment or charge.

8. Section eleven of the Finance (No. 2) Act, 1939 (which grants relief in respect of diminution of earned income owing to circumstances directly or indirectly connected with the present war) shall apply in relation to tax for the year 1941-42 as it applies in relation to tax for the year 1939-40, with the adaptation that references to the year 1939-40 shall be construed as references to the year 1941-42 and references to the year 1938-39 shall be construed as references to the year 1940-41.

9. — (1) This section applies to the relief to be granted under section thirty-two of the Income Tax Act, 1918 (which relates to life insurance premiums and other similar payments), for the year 1939-40 or any subsequent year of assessment for any part of which the Emergency Powers (Defence) Act, 1939, is in force.

(2) In paragraph (a) of subsection (3) of the said section thirty-two (which limits the amount in respect of which relief may be granted under that section to one-sixth of the taxpayer’s total income) the reference to total income shall be construed as a reference to total income for the year of assessment in question or total income for the year 1938-39, whichever is the higher.

10. — (1) Subject, as respects farming and farm land, to the provisions of the next succeeding section, farming and market gardening shall be treated as trades for the purposes of income tax and accordingly—

(a) the profits or gains thereof shall be charged under Case I of Schedule D; and

(b) income tax shall not be charged under Schedule B in respect of the occupation of any farm land or market garden land:

Provided that where land is farm land or market garden land for part only of the year of assessment, tax shall be charged under Schedule B on that land for that year on so much of the assessable value of that land as is apportionable to the remainder of that year, and any such apportionment shall be made by reference to the number of months or parts of a month in the said remainder of the year. 2 *

(2) For the purposes of this and the next succeeding section the following expressions have the meanings hereby respectively

assigned to them, that is to say,—

“ market garden land” means land occupied as a nursery or garden for the sale of the produce (other than land used for the growth of hops) and " market gardening ” shall be construed accordingly;

1941.

Finance Act, 1941.

Ch. 30.

207

“ farm land" means land wholly or mainly occupied for the purposes of husbandry, not being market garden land, and includes the farm house and farm buildings, if any, and “ farming " shall be construed accordingly;

“ land" means land in the United Kingdom;

“ period of computation ” means, in relation to a year of assessment, the period by reference to the profits or gains of which the profits or gains arising or accruing from farming are to be computed for that year.

(3) All the farming carried on by any particular person or partnership or body of persons shall be treated as one trade, and he or they shall be assessable and chargeable in respect of the profits or gains thereof in any of the parishes in which any part of his or their farm land is situated:

Provided that nothing in this subsection shall limit any right to make any assessment and charge in the place of ordinary residence.

(4) The question whether or not a trade has been discontinued or a new trade set up or commenced shall not, in the case of farming, be affected by the fact that, for particular years of assessment, the person or partnership or body of persons carrying on the farming is not or was not chargeable under Schedule D in respect thereof (whether by virtue of the next succeeding section or by reason of the fact that this section was not then m operation), and the period of computation for any year of assessment may, in the case of farming, be a period falling wholly or partly within a year or years of assessment for which the person, partnership or body of persons carrying on the farming was not chargeable under that Schedule. 5

(5) In considering, in relation to farming, whether any, and if so what, relief may be given to any person for the year 1941-42 or any subsequent year of assessment under section thirty-three of the Finance Act, 1926, or section twenty-nine of the Finance Act, 1927 (which relate to the carrying forward of losses) there may, if that person or a partnership of which he is a member is, by virtue of this section, chargeable under Schedule D for the year 1941-42 in respect of his or their farming, be carried forward to the year 1941-42 and subsequent years of assessment from the years of assessment preceding the year 1941-42 the amount (if any) which would have fallen to be carried forward to those years respectively if that person and every partnership of which he was a member had been charged under Schedule D in respect of his or their farming for all those preceding years and had been given in those preceding years all die relief which he or they could have been given under those sections if he or they had been so charged.

14. — (1) For the purpose of facilitating the recovery of tax assessed under Schedule A in respect of any land, the surveyor or the collector may serve on any person who is or has been liable to pay rent for the whole or any part of that land or is or has been in receipt of any such rent, whether on his own behalf or on behalf of another, a notice in the prescribed form requiring him to furnish, within such time as may be specified m the notice, such particulars with respect to the amount of the rent, the dates on which it is or was payable and the person to whom it is or was payable or, as the case may be, is or was accounted for, as may be so specified.

(2) Any person who fails to comply with the requirements of a notice duly served on him under this section, or, in furnishing the particulars required by any such notice, makes any statement which he knows to be false in any material particular or recklessly makes any statement which is false in any material particular, shall be liable to a penalty not exceeding fifty pounds.

16. — (1) Where—

(a) any land which is the subject of a short lease suffers war damage, and in consequence the lease comes to an end or the rent thereunder ceases to be payable or is reduced; and

(б) the Commissioners of Inland Revenue are satisfied that the lessee is unable to deduct tax which he would otherwise have been entitled to deduct under any of the Rules of No. VIII of Schedule A,

those Commissioners shall give to him, by repayment or otherwise, such relief from tax as will in their opinion reduce the amount of tax under Schedule A ultimately borne by him in respect of the land for the year of assessment (or that part thereof for which tax is payable) to what it would have been if the damage had not occurred.

(2) Where relief is given under subsection (1) of this section, the tax covered by the relief may be recovered from the persons by whom it would have ultimately been borne if the damage had not occurred, as if they had been respectively charged therewith and in the same way as any other tax charged on them may be recovered.

25. — (1) Subject to the provisions of this section, any provision, however worded, for the payment, whether periodically or otherwise, of a stated amount free of income tax, or free of income tax other than surtax, being a provision which—

(a) is contained in any deed or other instrument, in any will or codicil, in any order of any court, in any local or personal Act, or in any contract, whether oral or in writing; and

(b) was made before the third day of September, nineteen hundred and thirty-nine; and

(c) has not been varied on or after that date,

shall, as respects payments falling to be made during any year of assessment, the standard rate of income tax for which is ten shillings in the pound, have effect as if for the stated amount there were substituted an amount equal to twenty twenty-ninths thereof.

(2) Where any such provision as is mentioned in subsection

(1) of this section is a provision for a payment free of income tax (and not merely a provision for a payment free of income tax other than surtax) the sum, if any, to be paid under that provision to make good the requirement that the payment shall be free of surtax shall, in the case of surtax for the year preceding any such year of assessment as is mentioned in the said subsection (1), be reduced to twenty twenty-ninths of the sum which would have been sufficient for that purpose if the rates of surtax in force for the year 1937-38 had applied to the year for which the surtax is payable.

(3) A person who is entitled under any such provision as is mentioned in subsection (1) of this section to a payment free of

(a) the liability of the payee to account to the payor shall be limited to twenty twenty-ninths of the sum for which Re would have been accountable if the 1938-39 rates of income tax, other than surtax, had applied to the year of assessment in which the payment falls to be made, and the foregoing provisions of this section had not passed; and

27. — (1) For the purposes of the provisions of this Act relating to tax free payments—

(a) a provision, however worded, for the payment of such sum as will after deduction of income tax be equal to a stated amount, shall be treated as a provision for the payment of the said stated amount free of income tax, other than surtax; and

(б) the expression “ a stated amount " includes a stated fraction of the gross amount of any specified income (that is to say, of the amount of that income before income tax has been charged thereon, whether by deduction or otherwise), but does not include a stated fraction of the net amount of any specified income (that is to say, of the amount of that income after it has been charged to income tax, whether by deduction or otherwise);

(c) the expression “ if the 1938-39 rates of income tax, other than surtax, had applied " means, in relation to a year of assessment, if the standard rate of tax for the year had been five shillings and sixpence in the pound and the provisions of the Income Tax Acts relating to relief from tax had not been amended in any respect by any Act passed since the third day of September, nineteen hundred and thirty-nine.

(2) The Treasury may by regulations provide for adjustments between parties where payments to which the said provisions of this Act apply have been made before the passing of this Act otherwise than in accordance with those provisions.

of exceptional importance for the purposes of the prosecution of the war, the Treasury certify that an increase in output of the metal or oil over output at the normal rate is essential in the national interest, then, unless the certificate is revoked, the following provisions shall have effect.

(2) If the profits in any chargeable accounting period include profits attributable to additional output of the metal or oil due to the war, the standard profits of the trade or business for that chargeable accounting period shall, if the date by which the source of the metal or oil might, but for the war, have been expected to have been exhausted falls within one of the periods specified in the first column of the Second Schedule to this Act, be increased by not more than the percentage specified in relation to that period in the second column of that Schedule of an amount representing profit at the normal rate on that additional output.

33. — (1) The provisions of this section apply to any chargeable accounting period falling partly before and partly after the end of March, nineteen hundred and forty, and in this section—

(a) references to the whole period, the first part of the period, and the second part of the period shall be construed respectively as references to the whole of any such chargeable accounting period, so much thereof as falls before the said end of March, and so much thereof as falls after the said end of March;

(b) the expression “ excess profits” means the amount by which the profits for any period exceed the standard profits therefor;

(c) the expression “ the amending provisions" means the provisions of sections twenty-nine, thirty and thirty-one of this Act.

(2) The profits or loss of, and the standard profits for, the whole period shall be computed, first on the basis that the amending provisions do not apply to the period and secondly on the basis that the said provisions do apply to the period, and it shall then be ascertained, on each basis, whether there are excess profits or a deficiency of profits for the whole period, and if so what is the amount thereof.

(3) There shall be deemed to be, for the first part of the period, excess profits or a deficiency of profits, as the case may be, equal to an apportioned part of the excess profits or deficiency of profits ascertained under subsection (2) of this section on the first basis mentioned therein, and there shall be deemed to be, for the second part of the period, excess profits or a deficiency of profits, as the case may be, equal to an apportioned part of the excess profits or deficiency of profits ascertained under subsection (2) of this section on the second basis mentioned therein; and for the purpose of determining the rate at which excess profits tax is to be charged on any excess profits and of giving relief for deficiencies of profits under the enactments relating to excess profits tax, and for the purposes of section twenty-eight of this Act, the first part of the period and the second part of the period shall each be treated as if it were a separate chargeable accounting period.

Any apportionment required to be made by this subsection shall be made by reference to the number of months or fractions of months in each of the parts of the whole period.

(4) Subsection (3) of section twenty-six of the Finance Act, 1940, is hereby repealed.

Provided that if the total amount so disallowed is greater than the additional tax, the amounts which may be recovered from the said persons shall be reduced proportionately so that in all not more than an amount equal to the additional tax is recoverable.

A person shall be deemed for the purposes of this subsection to have paid additional tax as a consequence of a disallowance if and to the extent only that the total excess profits tax and national defence contribution paid exceeds the total excess profits tax and national defence contribution which would have been payable but for the disallowance.

(2) No sum shall be recoverable from any person under subsection (1) of this section unless within thirty days from the date on which a notification of the decision of the Commissioners under the said section thirty-two is served on the person carrying on the trade or business, or, in the case of a notification served before, or not later than two months after, the date of the passing of this Act, within three months from the date of the passing of this Act, the person carrying on the trade or business gives notice in writing to the inspector of taxes named in that behalf in the notification, and to the person to whom the disallowed fees or payments were payable, that the right of recovery conferred by this section is reserved against that person in relation to that disallowance; and where notice is so given, the person against whom the right is reserved may appeal to the Board of Referees against the decision of the Commissioners to make the disallowance.

(3) Where any sum is recovered under this section from any person, the income tax payable by him shall be computed as if the fees or payments in question had been reduced by the sum recovered, and relief shall be given accordingly by repayment or otherwise.

(a) for the purposes of the enactments relating to the relief for deficiencies of profits, his profits chargeable with excess profits tax; and

35. — (1) Where the Commissioners are of opinion that the main purpose for which any transaction or transactions was or were effected (whether before or after the passing of this Act) was the avoidance or reduction of liability to excess profits tax, they may, if they think fit, direct that such adjustments shall be made as respects liability to excess profits tax as they consider appropriate so as to counteract the avoidance or reduction of liability to excess profits tax which would otherwise be effected by the transaction or transactions.

(2) Without prejudice to the generality of the powers conferred by subsection (1) of this section, the powers conferred thereby extend—

(a) to the charging with excess profits tax of persons who, but for the adjustments, would not be chargeable with any tax, or would not be chargeable to the same extent;

(б) to the charging of a greater amount of tax than would be chargeable but for the adjustments.

37. — (1) Section eighteen of this Act (which relates to the treatment for income tax purposes of trades affected by certain arrangements for the concentration of industry or business) shall not affect the computation of profits for the purposes of excess

Erofits tax, but the following provisions of this section shall ave effect for the purposes of excess profits tax in relation to any arrangements to which that section applies.

(2) Where, in pursuance of any such arrangement?, a person ceases to carry on all or any of the activities theretofore carried on by him in connection with his trade or business, or undertakes activities not theretofore carried on by him in connection with his trade or business, the cessation or undertaking of the activities shall not be treated as effecting a discontinuance of that trade or business or the setting up or commencement of a new trade or business.

(3) Any sum becoming payable, in pursuance of any such arrangements, to, or to the successor of, any such person as is mentioned in the last preceding subsection by any other person who was or has become a party to the arrangements, not being either a sum in the nature of a capital payment or interest on borrowed money or other consideration given for the use of borrowed money, shall—

(a) be allowed as a deduction in computing the profits of the trade or business of the person by whom the said sum becomes payable; and

(b) be treated as a trading receipt of the person to whom the said sum becomes payable and be taken into account accordingly in computing the profits of the trade or business of that person.

1941. Finance Act, 1941. Ch. 30.

(4) Where a person who, in pursuance of any such arrangements, ceases to cany on all or any of the activities theretofore carried on by him in connection with his trade or business, is a partnership or a company the directors whereof have a controlling interest therein, any sum becoming payable, in pursuance of the arrangements, to a partner in, or director of, that partnership or company by any other person who was or has become a party to the arrangements, not being either a sum in the nature of a capital payment or interest on borrowed money or other consideration given for the use of borrowed money, shall be treated (for all the purposes of the enactments relating to excess profits tax, including the purposes of the last preceding subsection) as if it had become payable to the partnership or company and had then become payable by the partnership or company to the partner or director as a distribution of profits, or as directors' remuneration, as the case may be.

(5) Where, in pursuance of any such arrangements, plant or machinery of any such person as is mentioned in subsection (2) of this section remains unused during any period, the amount of any deduction allowable under paragraph 2 of Part I of the Seventh Schedule to the Finance (No. 2) Act, 1939, in respect of the wear and tear of that plant or machinery shall be computed as if the plant or machinery were in normal use.

(6) For the purposes of this section, the expression “ person " includes a partnership.

38. Paragraph 3 of Part I of the Seventh Schedule to the Finance (No. 2) Act, 1939 (which provides for an allowance for exceptional depreciation of certain assets) shall be amended in the manner set out in the Third Schedule to this Act.

39. — (1) Where for the purposes of excess profits tax the profits arising in any chargeable accounting period fall to be ascertained, then, in applying the definition of the expression “ income tax principles in subsection (1) of section fourteen of the Finance (No. 2) Act, 1939, regard shall be had to the income tax law m force with respect to the year of assessment in which that chargeable accounting period ends:

Provided that this subsection shall have effect subject to any provision of this or any other Act (whether parsed before or after this Act) which—

(a) applies to excess profits tax (with or without modifications) a specified provision of the law relating to die computation of profits or gains for the purposes of income tax; and

(б) directs that that provision shall apply to the computation for the purposes of excess profits tax of profits for specified chargeable accounting periods.

SCHEDULES.

FIRST SCHEDULE

Recovery etc. of tax assessed under Rule 8 of No. VII of

Schedule A.

Part I.

Provisions as to recovery from the landlord where he is not the person named in the assessment.

1. Legal proceedings shall not be instituted against a person as having been the landlord on the first day of January in the year of assessment (where he is not the person named in the assessment) until the expiration of twenty-one days from the service on him by the surveyor of a notice in writing, in the prescribed form, specifying the land and the amount of tax claimed and stating that it is mtended to proceed against him for the recovery thereof as having been the landlord of that land on the first day of January in the year of assessment for which the assessment was made.

2. Any person served with such a notice may appeal to the General Commissioners on giving within the said period of twenty-one days notice in writing to the surveyor of his intention to appeal and stating the grounds of his appeal.

3. Any such appeal may be against the amount of the assessment or may be founded upon the contention that the appellant was not the landlord of the land on the said first day of January:

Provided that no such appeal shall lie against the amount of the assessment if an appeal has already been brought against it by him or by any other person under any other provision of the Income Tax Acts.

4. If any appeal is brought under this Schedule, or if any appeal is pending under any other provision of the Income Tax Acts at the date of the service of the notice, no legal proceedings shall be instituted against any such person as is mentioned in paragraph 1 of this Schedule to recover the tax until the General Commissioners have determined the appeal.

5. Where no appeal is brought or is pending as aforesaid, it shall be conclusively presumed that the person on whom the notice was served was the landlord of the land on the said first day of January and that the amount of tax specified in the notice is due from him so far as it still remains unpaid; and where an appeal is brought or is pending as aforesaid, the same presumption shall be made except so far as it is inconsistent with the determination of the appeal.

Sections 12 and 15.

240

Ch. 30.

Finance A1941.

4 & 5 Geo. 6.

ist Sch. 6. A certificate of the surveyor as to any of the following matters, —cont. that is to say, the service of such a notice as aforesaid, the contents of the notice, and the fact that no appeal was brought or pending as aforesaid, a certificate of the clerk to the General Commissioners as to the bringing and the results of any such appeal, and a certificate of the collector that the sum specified in the certificate has become due and remains unpaid in respect of the tax in respect of the land in question, being, in any case, a certificate in the prescribed form, shall, in any legal proceedings, be sufficient evidence of the facts stated in the certificate; and any document purporting to be any such certificate as it is mentioned in this paragraph shall be deemed to be such a certificate until the contrary is proved.

7. A person on whom a notice is served under this Schedule shall not thereafter be entitled to give notice of appeal against the assessment under paragraph 3 of Part II of the First Schedule to the Finance Act, 1930.

8. This Schedule applies to the distraining of a person by his goods and chattels or the poinding of the goods and effects of a person as it applies to the institution of legal proceedings against him.

Part II.

Recovery by requiring payment over of rent.

1. The collector may serve a notice in writing in the prescribed form on the landlord for the time being or on any other person who receives any rent paid in respect of the whole or any part of the land to which the assessment relates (being rent received in the right of the landlord or by virtue of an assignment or mortgage of, or charge on, some right of the landlord in, or in rent from, the whole or some part of the land) requiring the landlord or other such person as aforesaid to pay to the collector in or towards the satisfaction of the tax any sums from time to time received on account of rent, or as the case may be, such rent as aforesaid, until the liability in respect of the tax has been satisfied, and the person on whom the notice is served shall pay all such sums over to the collector accordingly and, if he is accountable for the rent to any other person, he shall be acquitted and discharged as against that other person by the payment.

2. If any landlord or other person on whom a notice has been duly served as aforesaid fails to comply with the requirements of the notice, he shall, in respect of each payment of rent with respect to which any such failure occurs, be liable to a penalty not exceeding fifty pounds.

Part III.

Recovery from occupiers.

1. The collector may from time to time by notice in writing in the prescribed form demand from the occupiers for the time being of all or any of the parts of the house or building payment, on the date or dates specified in the notice, of such sum or sums as may be required to satisfy the tax:

1941. Finance Act 1941. Ch. 30.

Provided that—

(a) no such notice shall demand from the occupier of any part payment of any sum on a date after the last date on which rent becomes due from him in respect of that part; and

(б) the sum demanded from the occupier of any part to be paid during any period during which rent is accruing due from him in respect of that part shall not exceed the amount of that rent becoming due at the end of that period.

2. In default of payment by any occupier of any amount duly demanded of him under this Part of this Schedule, that amount may be recovered from him in like manner as if he had been charged with tax of that amount.

3. Where any sum on account of the tax has been collected from an occupier in pursuance of this Part of this Schedule, he may deduct that sum from any subsequent payment on account of rent and shall be acquitted and discharged of the amount so deducted.

FOURTH SCHEDULE.

Provisions as to Groups of Companies.

1. Subsection (2) of section twenty-six of the Finance Act, 1940 (which contains provisions for securing that deficiencies occurring after the end of March, nineteen hundred and forty, shall, so far as possible, be applied to reduce profits arising after the said end of March and deficiencies

(a) the references to profits (except in the phrase “ deficiency of profits ") shall be construed as including all profits on which the principal company is assessable to excess profits tax; and

(б) the references to profits arising in another chargeable accounting period shall be construed as including references to profits arising in the same period but to another member of the group,

and the said subsection (2), so construed, shall have effect notwithstanding anything in sub-paragraph (2) of paragraph 6 of Part IV of the Fifth Schedule to the Finance Act, 1940 (which relates to deficiencies of members of groups of companies) as well as anything in subsection (2) of section fifteen of the Finance (No. 2) Act, 1939*

The reference in this paragraph to profits on which the principal company is assessable has the same meaning as in the said sub-paragraph (2) of paragraph 6 of Part TV of the Fifth Schedule to the Finance Act, 1940.

2. Section twenty-eight of this Act (which provides for the repayment after the war of certain excess profits tax) shall, in relation to any body corporate which at any time while the tax is at the rate of a hundred per cent, is a member of a group of companies, have effect subject to such adaptations and modifications as may be prescribed by the Commissioners.

3. In section twenty-nine of this Act, and in section twenty-seven of the Finance Act, 1940, as amended by the said section twenty, the expression “ borrowed money " shall not include any borrowed money the debt in respect whereof is such a debt as is mentioned in subsection (1) or subsection (ia) of section seventeen of the Finance (No. 2) Act, 1939.

4. Section thirty of this Act (which relates to losses) shall, in relation to a member of a group of companies the trades or businesses of none of the members of which were being carried on on or before the first day of July, nineteen hundred and thirty-six, have effect subject to the following modifications—

(a) an increase shall only be allowed under subsection (1) thereof if the aggregation of all the profits and losses of all the trades or businesses of all the members of the group over the period mentioned in the said subsection (1) shows a net loss, and if such an increase is allowed, it shall in no case exceed such part of that net loss as may be determined by the Commissioners;

(б) for the purpose of ascertaining whether the condition specified in subsection (4) thereof is fulfilled, all the trades or businesses of all the members of the group shall be treated as one trade or business;

j (c) if the principal company is dissatisfied with any determination 1 of the Commissioners under sub-paragraph (a) of this para-

graph, it may appeal to the Board of Referees.
