Marriage (Members of His Majesty's Forces) Act, 1941.

Ch. 47.

413

CHAPTER 47.

An Act to provide further facilities for the marriage of members of His Majesty’s forces (including women’s services) during the war period, and to amend the Marriage (Naval, Military and Air Force Chapels) Act, 1932.

[nth November 1941.]

BE it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows :—

1. — (1) Where the parties to an intended marriage have duly fulfilled all the conditions required by law for enabling them to be married in a building in England, then, if either of the parties, being a member of His Majesty’s forces, has obtained from the appropriate authority a certificate that owing to the exigencies of His Majesty's service he or she cannot go to that building and that the said authority has no reason to believe that he or she is already married, the marriage may, during the war period—

(a) be lawfully solemnized in any other building in England in which marriages may be lawfully solemnized, as if the parties had duly fulfilled all the conditions required by law for enabling them to be married in that building; or

(b) be lawfully celebrated by a minister in Scotland, or contracted in the office of an authorised registrar in Scotland, as if the parties had duly fulfilled all the conditions required by law for enabling the marriage to be so celebrated or contracted.

(2) Where the parties to an intended marriage have duly fulfilled all the conditions required by law for enabling a marriage between them to be celebrated or contracted in Scotland, then, if either of the parties, being a member of His Majesty's forces, has obtained from the appropriate authority a certificate that owing to the exigencies of His Majesty’s service he or she cannot go to Scotland to be married there, and that the said authority has no reason to believe that he or she is already married, the marriage may, during the war period, be lawfully solemnized in any building in England in which marriages may lawfully be solemnized, as if the parties thereto had duly fulfilled all the conditions required by law for enabling them to be married in that building.

Alteration of place of marriage

414

Extension of time for marriage.

4 Geo. 4. c. 76.

Power to issue marriage licence forthwith after notice of marriage.

Ch. 47. Marriage (Members of 4 & 5 Geo. 6.

His Majesty's Forces) Act, 1941.

2. — (1) The following provisions of this section shall have effect, notwithstanding anything in any other enactment, as respects the time within which a marriage may be solemnized, celebrated or contracted in cases where, at the time when the marriage is solemnized, celebrated or contracted, one at least of the parties thereto is a member of His Majesty’s forces—

(a) if publication of the banns has been completed (whether

before or after the commencement of this Act) in accordance with the provisions of the Marriage Act, 1823, the marriage may be solemnized in England at any time during the war period within one year after the complete publication of the banns, and any certificate granted with respect thereto shall have effect accordingly;

(б) if a licence for the marriage has been granted (whether

before or after the commencement of this Act) by an archbishop, bishop, ordinary or other person having authority to grant such a licence, the marriage may be solemnized in England at any time during the war period within one year after the grant of the licence, and the licence shall have effect accordingly;

(c) if notice of the marriage has been entered and a certificate thereon granted (whether before or after the commencement of this Act) by a superintendent registrar in England, the marriage may be solemnized in England or celebrated or contracted in Scotland at any time during the war period within one year after the entry of the notice, and the notice and certificate and any licence which may have been granted thereon shall have effect accordingly;

(d) if notice of the marriage has been given to, and a certificate thereon granted by, a registrar in Scotland (whether before or after the commencement of this Act), the marriage may be solemnized in England or celebrated or contracted in Scotland at any time during the war period within one year after the date of the certificate, and the notice and certificate shall have effect accordingly.

(2) The reference in paragraph (a) of the foregoing subsection to the provisions of the Marriage Act, 1823, shall be construed as including a reference to those provisions as amended or applied by any subsequent enactment.

3. Where—

(a) a superintendent registrar in England receives during the war period notice of an intended marriage to be solemnized by licence; and

1941- Marriage (Members of Ch. 47.

His Majesty’s Forces) Act, 1941.

(b) one at least of the parties to the intended marriage is a member of His Majesty's forces;

the Registrar General may, notwithstanding anything in section nine of the Marriage and Registration Act, 1856 (which provides that the certificate and licence to marry mentioned in that section shall not be issued until the expiration of one whole day after the day of entry of the notice) authorise the superintendent registrar to issue such a certificate and licence forthwith after entry of the notice.

4. Subsection (2) of section one of the Marriage (Naval, Military and Air Force Chapels) Act, 1932 (which describes the persons qualified to marry in a chapel to which the Act applies) shall have effect as if the following paragraph were substituted for paragraph (d) thereof (which relates to the nursing service) :—

“ (d) is a woman actually employed in any capacity specified in the First Schedule to the Marriage (Members of His Majesty’s Forces) Act, 1941, as amended by any Order in Council for the time being in force under that Act, in the service of any force mentioned in the foregoing paragraphs of this subsection; ”

5. — (1) For the purposes of this Act, the expression “ member of His Majesty's forces " means—

(a) a man, being a member of any of His Majesty’s naval,

military or air forces; or

(b) a woman in the service of any of His Majesty’s naval,

military or air forces in any capacity respectively specified in Part I, Part II or Part III of the First Schedule to this Act.

(2) His Majesty may by Order in Coungil direct that, subject to any exceptions specified in the Order, there shall be added to Part I, Part II or Part III of the said Schedule, women in the service of any of His Majesty’s naval, military or air forces respectively in such capacities as may be specified in the Order.

(3) For the purposes of this Act, the expression “ appropriate authority ” in relation to a member of His Majesty’s forces of any description specified in the first column of the Second Schedule to this Act, means the authority respectively specified in the second column of that Schedule.

(4) A certificate stating that—

(a) a person named in the certificate is a member of His Majesty's forces for the purposes of this Act; and

(b) that the person signing the certificate is the appropriate

authority for the purposes of this Act in relation to that person;

shall be conclusive evidence for the purposes of this Act of the facts so stated.

CHAPTER 48.

An Act to extend the duration of the present Parliament.

[nth November 1941."

BE it enacted by the King's most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritui and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows:—

1. Section seven of the Parliament Act, 1911, (which provides that five years shall be substituted for seven yean as the time fixed for the maximum duration of Parliament under the Septennial Act 1715) shall not apply to the present Parliament.

2. This Act may be cited as the Prolongation of Parliament Act, 1941.

9. — (1) Where, whether before or after the commencement of this Act,—

(a) possession has been taken of any land for agricultural purposes by the Minister or by the Committee in the exercise of any power conferred by Defence Regulations; and

(b) the Minister, on the advice of the Committee, has certified

that at the time possession was so taken, the land was not being cultivated, or was not being cultivated in accordance with the rules of good husbandry; and

(c) the Minister, on the advice of the Committee, has further

certified that the value of the land has been or will be substantially increased by things which have been done, or which it is intended should be done, on the land by, or by arrangement with, the Minister or the Committee,

then, for the purpose of preserving for the Crown the benefit of that increase in value, the Minister may acquire and resell the land in accordance with the provisions of this and the next succeeding section, and, pending the resale, may create such tenancies, easements and other rights, make such contracts and do such things in relation to the land as will in his opinion conduce to the proper management and cultivation of that or any neighbouring land.

(2) The Minister may acquire the land either by agreement or compulsorily, and for the purposes of the acquisition thereof, the Lands Clauses Acts shall be incorporated with this Act, subject, however, to the provisions of the Acquisition of Land (Assessment of Compensation) Act, 1919, to the adaptations and modifications set out in the Fourth Schedule to this Act and to the following provisions of this section:

Provided that no land shall be acquired under this section unless the contract for the acquisition thereof is made, or, as the case may be, the notice to treat is served, while the Minister or the Committee still continue in possession of the land, either by himself or themselves or by any person occupying the land under an occupation contract.

(3) In determining the amount of compensation to be given for any land acquired compulsorily under this section, the value of that land shall be taken to be the price which a willing seller would, at the date of the notice to treat, have been likely to obtain in the open market for the land if it had remained in the condition in which it was at the time when possession was taken by the Minister or the Committee, as the case may be, and such reduction, if any, shall be made in the compensation as is necessary in order to off-set any appreciation in the value of the land which is directly or indirectly ascribable to the war.

(4) For the purposes of section sixteen of the War Damage Act, 1941 (which relates to the payment to be made in a case where land which has sustained war damage, is, before the damage has been fully made good, acquired compulsorily by virtue of an enactment passed before the passing of that Act), this Act shall be deemed to have been passed before that Act, and, where land is acquired under this section, no value payment shall be made under that Act in respect of any damage to the land occurring after possession of the land had been taken by the Minister or the Committee, as the case may be.

(5) On the acquisition by the Minister under this section of any land which is the subject of an occupation contract, that contract shall, as from the date of the acquisition, have effect for all purposes (including the purposes of the next succeeding section) as if it had created a tenancy granted by the Minister;

Provided that the Agricultural Holdings Act, 1923, shall not, by virtue of this subsection, apply in relation to any such tenancy except in so far as it was incorporated in the occupation contract.

(6) Nothing in this section shall authorise the acquisition of any land which is, or forms part of, a metropolitan common within the meaning of the Metropolitan Commons Act, 1866, or which is subject, or might be made subject, to regulation under an order or scheme made in pursuance of the Inclosure Acts, 1845 to 1882, or under any local Act or otherwise, or which

10. — (1) Where the Minister has acquired any land under the last preceding section, he shall, at such time as he thinks fit but not in any case more than five years after the end of the war period, make to such person as is mentioned in subsection (2) of this section such an offer as is mentioned in subsection (3) thereof:

Provided that the Minister shall not be under any obligation to make any such offer in the case of any land if, at the time when he would otherwise have made such an offer in the case of that land, either—

(a) after such advertisement and enquiry as appears to the Minister to be reasonable, no such person can be found; or

(б) the Minister, after having given an opportunity to any

persons appearing to him as likely to be affected of making representations and considered any such representations made, certifies that in his opinion the result of the making and acceptance of such an offer would be that the land could not or would not be properly managed and cultivated.

(2) The person to whom the said offer shall be made shall—

(a) where, when possession of the land was taken by the

Minister or the Committee, the land formed part of an estate, and, when the offer is made, some person owns at least two-thirds (in area) of the land which was comprised in that estate, be that person; and

(б) in any other case, be such person, if any, as, in the

opinion of the Minister, is proper to be treated as the person who would, but for the acquisition of the land by the Minister, own the land.

In this subsection, the expression “ estate” means land managed as one unit by or on behalf of the owner thereof (whether or not parts of it are farmed or occupied by different persons) and the expression “ own” means own in fee simple, whether or not subject to any mortgage of tenancy, and includes owning as a tenant for life or in any other fiduciary capacity.

(3) The said offer shall be an offer to sell the land for an estate in fee simple absolute in possession, subject however to any tenancies, easements or other rights which existed when the Minister acquired the land or were granted by the Minister in so far as they are still subsisting at the date of the offer, at such price as may be specified in the offer or, if the person to whom the offer is made so elects in accepting the offer, at such price as may be agreed, or, in default of agreement, as may be determined by arbitration to be the price which a willing seller would at the date of the offer have been likely to obtain in the open market:

Provided that, where the price or compensation paid by the Minister for the acquisition of the land from the person to whom the offer is made or his predecessor in title included a sum in respect of severance from, or injurious affection of, other land, and the damage for which that sum was paid will be wholly or partly made good to the person to whom the offer is made by his availing himself of the offer, the Minister, in considering what price he is prepared to accept, and the arbitrator, in determining wffiat price is to be paid, shall include therein such sum as corresponds to the damage so made good, not exceeding the sum included as aforesaid in the price or compensation paid by the Minister.

(4) An offer made under the last preceding subsection shall remain open for three months from the date of the making thereof and shall not be capable of being withdrawn before the expiration of that period.

(6) Where such an offer as aforesaid is made and lapses or is duly withdrawn, or where for any reason no such offer has to be made, the Minister may resell the land when, to wffiom and in wffiat manner he thinks fit; and the title of a purchaser of any land from the Minister shall not be impeachable on the ground of the failure of the Minister to make such an offer as aforesaid or of any irregularity in relation to any such offer, and such a purchaser shall not, either before or on conveyance, be concerned to see or inquire whether or not there has been any such failure or irregularity.

11. — (1) For the purpose of preventing the spreading of pests or diseases among bees, the Minister may by order provide—

(a) for obtaining information as to the persons who keep

bees, and as to the occurrence of any such pest or disease affecting bees as may be specified in the order;

(b) for the inspection of bees and combs, and of hives,

containers, and other appliances used in connection therewith;

(c) for prohibiting or restricting the movement of bees and

combs, and of any such appliances as aforesaid;

(d) for determining whether any bees or combs, or any such appliances as aforesaid, are infected, or have been exposed to infection, with any pest or disease specified in the order, and for the destruction or treatment of any bees, combs or appliances determined to be so infected or to have been exposed to such infection;

(e) for such incidental and supplementary matters as may be necessary or expedient.

(2) The Minister shall appoint an advisory committee for the purposes of this section, and shall exercise the powers conferred on him by subsection (1) of this section and, to such extent as may be provided in any order made thereunder, the powers conferred on him by any such order, after consultation with that committee.

(3) If any person contravenes or fails to comply with the provisions of any order made under this section, he shall be liable, on summary conviction, to a fine not exceeding twenty pounds.

(4) Any order made under this section may be revoked or varied by a subsequent order thereunder.

(5) The expenses incurred by the Minister in exercising his powers under this section or under any order made thereunder shall be defrayed out of moneys provided by Parliament.

(6) In this section the term “ bees” means honey bees, and includes such bees in any stage of their life cycle.

SCHEDULES

FIRST SCHEDULE.

Provisions of the Agriculture (Miscellaneous War Provisions) Act, 1940, applied, with Adaptations and Modifications, to Local Drainage Districts.

Section fourteen

14. — (1) Where the War Agricultural Executive Committee for a county or county borough consider that any agricultural land within the county or borough, being land within a local drainage district, is capable of improvement by the execution of drainage works, they may request the drainage board for that district to prepare and carry out a scheme for draining the land.

(2) After receiving such a request as respects any land, the board may prepare a scheme for draining the land, if they are of opinion—

(a) that the cost of preparing and carrying out the scheme will

not exceed an amount equal to ten pounds for each acre of the land; and

(b) that the value of the land for agricultural purposes will be

increased in consequence of the carrying out of the scheme.

(3) The provisions of the Fifth Schedule to this Act shall have effect with respect to the contents and approval by the Minister of a scheme under this section and to the notices to be given in relation thereto.

1941.

Agriculture

(Miscellaneous Provisions) Act, 1941.

Ch. 50.

(4) Where a scheme prepared by a drainage board under this section has been approved by the Minister—

(a) the board may execute any works specified in the scheme, and for that purpose shall have all the powers which are exercisable by them under the Land Drainage Act, 1930, in relation to land in their district; and

(б) the owner of any land comprised in the area of the scheme

shall be liable to pay to the board, within one month after the date of a demand made in writing by the board, the amount apportioned under the scheme to that land of the net cost of the scheme:

Provided that an owner by whom any amount is so payable may, by notice in writing served on the board within the said one month, elect to pay the said amount, together with interest thereon from the said date, by such number of equal annual instalments, not exceeding five, as may be specified in the notice, so, however, that—

(i) the first such instalment shall be payable within one year

from the said date; and

(ii) the rate of interest shall, in default of agreement between the owner and the board, be fixed by the Minister.

(5) Any sum payable to a board under the last foregoing subsection—

(a) may be recovered by the board summarily as a civil debt; and

(б) shall be a charge on the land in respect of which it is payable;

and the board shall, for the‘purpose of enforcing any such charge, have the same powers and remedies under the Law of Property Act, 1925, and otherwise as they would have if they were mortgagees by deed, having powers of sale and lease, of accepting surrenders of leases and of appointing a receiver.

(6) Where, on the termination of the tenancy of a holding within the meaning of the Agricultural Holdings Act, 1923, in respect of which any sum has been paid or is payable to a board by virtue of a scheme under this section, the landlord proves to the satisfaction of an arbitrator appointed under that Act that any works executed in pursuance of the scheme were rendered necessary by the neglect of the tenant to comply with any obligation relating to the maintenance or repair of a watercourse imposed on him by virtue of the contract of tenancy, the arbitrator shall award the landlord compensation equal to so much of the net cost of the scheme as was attributable to the execution of those works:

Provided that, where any agreement is made between the landlord and the tenant of such a holding as aforesaid for the payment by the tenant of any contribution in respect of the sum paid or payable as aforesaid, that contribution shall be recoverable from the tenant in lieu of compensation under this subsection.

For the purposes of any arbitration under this subsection, a certificate by the board that such part of the net cost of the scheme as may be specified in the certificate was attributable to the execution of works so specified shall be conclusive evidence of that fact.

Fifth Schedule.

Provisions as to certain drainage schemes.

1. Every scheme shall set out—

(a) the area of the land to be drained in pursuance of the scheme;

(ft) a description of the works proposed to be executed in pursuance of the scheme;

(c) the estimated cost of preparing and carrying out the scheme;

(d) the amount of any grant which will, if the scheme is approved by the Minister, be made by him to the board towards the expenditure incurred by the board in preparing and carrying out the scheme; and

(e) the basis of apportionment, as between the lands comprised in

the area of the scheme, of the net cost of the scheme.

2. When the board have prepared the scheme, they may submit it to the Minister for his approval, and he may approve it either without modification or with any modifications which he considers expedient.

6. If the scheme is not approved by the Minister, no further proceedings shall be taken thereon by the board.

7. If the scheme is approved by the Minister, the board shall as soon as may be serve on the owners of land comprised in the area of the scheme a notice stating that the scheme has been approved, and every such notice shall contain a copy of the scheme.

SECOND SCHEDULE.

Section 6.

Recovery from Drainage Boards of Expenses of Certain Drainage Works.

1. The Minister shall serve on the drainage board, within one year from the completion of the work or from the constitution of the drainage board, whichever is the later, a notice specifying the amount of the expenses which the board is required to pay, and the said expenses shall become recoverable as a debt due to His Majesty at the expiration of one year from the date of the service of the notice and shall, without prejudice to any other mode for the recovery thereof, be recoverable by the Minister summarily as a civil debt.

2. The drainage board may, by notice in writing served on the Minister at any time within one year from the date of the service of the notice by the Minister under the foregoing paragraph, elect to pay the said expenses, together with interest thereon from the date on which the expenses would otherwise have become recoverable from the board, by such number of equal annual instalments, not exceeding five, as may be specified in the notice:

Provided that—

(a) the first instalment shall be payable within one year from the last-mentioned date; and

(£>) the rate of interest shall, in default of agreement between the board and the Minister, be fixed by the Treasury.

3. Where the drainage board do not exercise the powers conferred on them by paragraph 2 of this Schedule, they may borrow money under section forty-six of the Land Drainage Act, 1930, for the purpose of defraying the said expenses as if those expenses were expenses incurred by them under that Act.

4. Notwithstanding anything in subsection (2) of section twenty-four of the Land Drainage Act, 1930, a rate raised by a drainage board for the purpose of defraying any sums they are required to pay under this Schedule shall be an owners' drainage rate.

Provisions applicable to Recovery of Expenses from Owners of Land.

1. A proportion of the expenses shall be recoverable as a debt due to His Majesty from each owner of land the value of which will be increased by the doing of the work on whom a notice in writing requiring payment thereof is served by the Minister within one year from the completion of the work, and shall, without prejudice to any other mode for the recovery thereof, be recoverable by the Minister summarily as a civil debt.

2. A notice served for the purposes of the preceding paragraph shall specify the sum which the owner on whom it is served is required to pay and the land in respect of which he is required to pay it, and that sum shall not exceed either of the following limits, that is to say,—

(a) the amount by which the value for agricultural purposes of the specified land will be increased by the doing of the work;

(b) the same proportion of the expenses as the amount aforesaid bears to the amount by which the value for agricultural purposes of all the land affected will be increased by the doing of the work.

3. Subject to the provisions of the two next succeeding paragraphs, the sum specified in such a notice shall become recoverable at the expiration of three months from the date of the service thereof.

4. If an owner on whom such a notice is served claims that none of the land in his ownership will be increased in value for agricultural purposes by the doing of the work, or that the sum specified in the notice exceeds either of the limits mentioned in paragraph 2 of this Schedule, he may, by notice in writing served on the Minister at any time within the said three months, require his claim to be referred for determination by a single arbitrator appointed by agreement between him and the Minister, or, in default of such agreement, by the President of the Chartered Surveyors’ Institution and, if he does so, no sum shall be recoverable from him until his claim has been so determined, and—

(a) if it is determined that none of the land in his ownership will

be increased in value as aforesaid, no part of the expenses shall be recoverable from him;

(b) if it is determined that the sum specified exceeds either of

the said limits, the sum recoverable from him shall be that sum less such amount as the arbitrator may determine to be requisite in order to bring it within those limits.

5. An owner on whom a notice for the purposes of paragraph 1 of this Schedule is served may, by notice in writing served on the Minister at any time within the said three months, or, if he has claimed a reference under the last preceding paragraph, at any time within one month from the date on which his claim has been determined, elect to pay any sum recoverable from him under this Schedule, together with interest thereon from the date on which that amount would otherwise have become recoverable from him, by such number of equal annual instalments, not exceeding five, as may be specified in his notice:

Provided that—

(a) the first instalment shall be payable within one year from

the last-mentioned date; and

(b) the rate of interest shall, in default of agreement between

the owner and the Minister, be fixed by the Treasury.

FOURTH SCHEDULE.

Adaptations and Modifications of the Lands Clauses Acts.

1. This Act shall be deemed to be the Special Act, references to the promoters of the undertaking shall be construed as references to the Minister, and the undertaking shall be deemed to be the cultivation of the land for agricultural purposes.

2. The following provisions of the Lands Clauses Consolidation Act, 1845, that is to say,—

(a) sections eighty-four to ninety-one (which relate to entry upon

the land acquired);

(b) sections one hundred and twenty-seven to one hundred and

thirty-three (which relate to the sale of superfluous land and

deficiencies of land-tax and rates); and

(c) sections one hundred and fifty and one hundred and fifty-one

(which relate to access to the Special Act), shall not apply.

3. Such adjustment shall be made in the compensation payable in respect of the acquisition of any land compulsorily acquired as may be just, having regard to any payment of, or right to, compensation under the Compensation (Defence) Act, 1939, in respect of the taking of possession of the land under Defence Regulations; and any such adjustment may, if the arbitrator thinks fit, take the form of a direction that the compensation payable to any person on the acquisition of the land shall be wholly or partly conditional on his relinquishing any such right, to such extent as is specified in the direction.

4. Where the land acquired is glebe land or other land belonging to an ecclesiastical benefice, sums agreed upon or awarded by way of compensation shall not be paid as directed by the Lands Clauses Acts, but shall be paid to the Ecclesiastical Commissioners to be applied by them as money paid to them upon a sale under the provisions of the Ecclesiastical Leasing Acts of land belonging to a benefice.

Arthur Jenkins Indemnity Act, 1941.

Indemnity for and removal of disqualification of Arthur J enkins, Esquire.

Short title

5 Geo. 6.

CHAPTER 1.

An Act to indemnify Arthur Jenkins, Esquire, from any penal consequence which he may have incurred by sitting or voting as a member of the House of Commons while holding the office of Chairman of the Local Appeal Board for a Royal Ordnance Factory, and to remove any disqualification for membership of that House by reason of his having held that office.

[10th December 1941]

BE it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows :—

1. Arthur Jenkins, Esquire, shall be and is hereby freed discharged and indemnified from all penal consequences whatsoever incurred by him by sitting or voting as a member of the Commons House of Parliament while holding the office of Chairman of the Local Appeal Board for a Royal Ordnance Factory, and shall be deemed not to have been or to be incapable of sitting or voting as a member of that House by reason only of his having held that office at any time before the passing of this Act.

2. This Act may be cited as the Arthur Jenkins Indemnity Act, 1941.

5 & 6 Geo. 6.

CHAPTER 2.

An Act to apply a sum out of the Consolidated Fund to the service of the year ending on the thirty-first day of March, one thousand nine hundred and forty-two.

[18th December 1941.]

Most Gracious Sovereign,

WE, Your Majesty’s most dutiful and loyal subjects, the Commons of the United Kingdom in Parliament assembled, towards making good the supply which we have cheerfully granted to Your Majesty in this session of Parliament, have

b>

1941.

Consolidated Fund (No. i)

Act, 1941 ( S2).

Ch. 2.

441

resolved to grant unto Your Majesty the sum hereinafter mentioned; and do therefore most humbly beseech Your Majesty that it may be enacted, and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows:—

1. The Treasury may issue out of the Consolidated Fund of the United Kingdom and apply towards making good the supply granted to His Majesty for the service of the year ending on the thirty-first day of March, one thousand nine hundred and forty-two, the sum of one thousand million pounds.

2. — (1) The Treasury may borrow from any person by the issue of Treasury Bills or otherwise, and the Bank of England and the Bank of Ireland may advance to the Treasury on the credit of the said sum, any sum or sums not exceeding in the whole one thousand million pounds.

(2) The date of payment of any Treasury Bills issued under this section shall be a date not later than the thirty-first day of March, one thousand nine hundred and forty-two, and section six of the Treasury Bills Act, 1877 (which relates to the renewal of bills), shall not apply with respect to those bills.

(3) Any money borrowed otherwise than on Treasury Bills shall be repaid, with interest not exceeding three pounds per centum per annum, out of the growing produce of the Consolidated Fund, at any period not later than the next succeeding quarter to that in, which the money was borrowed.

(4) Any money borrowed under this section shall be placed to the credit of the account of the Exchequer, and shall form part of the said Consolidated Fund, and be available in any manner in which such Fund is available.

(5) The interest on any money borrowed under this section shall be paid out of the permanent annual charge for the National Debt.

3. This Act may be cited as the Consolidated Fund (No. 1) Act, 1941 (Session 2).

Continuance of Acts in Schedule. CHAPTER 3. An Act to continue certain expiring laws.

[18th December 1941.] \*7HEREAS the Acts mentioned in the Schedule to this Act are, in so far as they are in force and are temporary in their duration, limited to expire— (a) as respects those mentioned in Part I of the said Schedule, on the thirty-first day of December nineteen hundred and forty-one, and (б) as respects that mentioned in Part II of the said Schedule on the thirty-first day of March nineteen hundred and forty-two: And whereas it is expedient to provide for the continuance, as in this Act mentioned, of those Acts and of the enactments amending or affecting the same : Be it therefore enacted by the King's most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows' 1. — (1) The Acts mentioned in Part I of the Schedule to this Act shall, to the extent specified in column three of that Part of that Schedule, be continued until the thirty-first day of December nineteen hundred and forty-two. CHAPTER 4.

An Act to amend the law as to the liability to national service.

[18th December 1941]

BE it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows :—

General

obligation to serve.

4 & 5 Geo. 6 c. 15.

General obligation to serve.

1. It is hereby declared that all persons of either sex for the time being in Great Britain are liable to national service, whether under the Crown or not, and whether in the armed forces of the Crown, in civil defence, in industry, or otherwise:

Provided that—

(a) the liability of any person to whole-time service in the armed forces of the Crown or in or with a civil defence force within the meaning of the National Service Act, 1941, shall be such as may be imposed upon him under the National Service Acts, 1939 to 1941;

-

1941.

National Service (No. 2)

Act, 1941.

Ch. 4.

445

(6) the liability of any person to any other form of national service (including part-time service in the armed forces of the Crown or in or with such a civil defence force as aforesaid) shall be such as may be imposed upon him under Defence Regulations;

(c) nothing in this section shall relieve any person from any liability to national service which he would be under apart from this section.

Amendments of National Service Acts, 1939 to 1941.

2. — (1) In section one of the National Service (Armed Forces) Act, 1939 (hereinafter referred to as the “ principal Act ”), for the words •“ forty-one years," wherever those words occur, there shall be substituted the words “fifty-one years

(2) Where a person who becomes liable to be called up by virtue of this section had, before the passing of this Act, become liable to be called up but had ceased to be so liable on attaining the age of forty-one years—

(a) he shall not be treated as prevented from making an

application for a postponement certificate by reason that he had previously made an application for such a certificate before the passing of this Act, whatever the result of the previous application;

(b) if his medical examination was completed before the

passing of this Act, the Minister may, if, in all the circumstances, he thinks that it is appropriate so to do, refrain from dismissing an application by him for a postponement certificate, notwithstanding that the application is made more than two days after the completion of his medical examination and that the delay in making the application is not related to the grounds thereof.

3. — (1) The National Service Acts, 1939 to 1941, shall, subject to the provisions of this section, apply in relation to women as they apply in relation to men:

Provided that proclamations under section one of the principal Act may apply either to men only or to women only or to both men and women, and may make different provision in relation to men and women.

(2) The forces for service in which a woman shall be liable to be called up under the principal Act shall (without prejudice to her liability to be called up for civil defence under the National Service Act, 1941) be the Women's Royal Naval Service, the Auxiliary Territorial Service and the Women’s Auxiliary Air Force, and references in the principal Act and this

Extension of age to fifty.

Act to the armed forces of the Crown shall, in relation to women, be construed accordingly; and in subsection (1) of section four of the principal Act, references to entering or enlistment (except in the phrase “ an enlistment notice ”) shall, in relation to women, be construed as including references to enrolment:

Provided that subsection (1) of section eleven of the principal Act (which provides for exemptions from liability to be called up) shall have effect, in relation to women, as if for the exemption provided by paragraph (c) thereof for members of the armed forces of the Crown there were substituted an exemption for women of any of the classes specified in the Schedule to this Act, not being women whose enrolment or other undertaking to serve was for part time service only or for service without remuneration.

(3) At the end of subsection (1) of the said section eleven, the following words shall be inserted:—

" or

(h) is a married woman not living apart from her husband under a decree or order of any court or a woman who has living with her a child of hers under the age of fourteen (including a step-child and an illegitimate child, and, if the adoption took place before the passing of this Act, an adopted child (whether adopted under the Adoption of Children Act, 1926, the Adoption of Children (Scotland) Act, 1930, or otherwise)).”

(4) No woman who is called up for service under the principal Act shall be required actually to use any lethal weapon or to take part in the actual use of any lethal weapon unless she has signified in writing her willingness to use lethal weapons or, as the case may be, to take part in the use thereof.

4. — (1) Where, whether before or after the passing of this Act, a person who—

(a) has at any time since the third day of September,

nineteen hundred and thirty-nine, served in the armed forces of the Crown (other than the Home Guard), or

(b) has been called up for civil defence under the National

Service Act, 1941,

has been discharged, he shall be liable to be called up whether or not any proclamation under section one of the principal Act is applicable to him:

Provided that this subsection shall not affect any exemption existing by virtue of section five or section eleven of the principal Act.

(2) The exemption provided by paragraph (c) of subsection (1) of section eleven of the principal Act, the exemption substituted

therefor in the case of women by the last preceding section, and the exemption provided by paragraph of subsection (1) of section three of the National Service Act, 1941, shall not prevent the service of an enlistment or enrolment notice on a member of the armed forces of the Crown or of a civil defence force within the meaning of the National Service Act, 1941, and a notice served on any such member by virtue of this subsection shall have effect notwithstanding that there is no proclamation under section one of the principal Act applicable to him and notwithstanding that he has not been medically examined under that Act:

Provided that, if the person on whom a notice is served by virtue of this subsection is not discharged on or before the day on which he is required by the notice to present himself to the authority specified in the notice, the notice shall be void.

(3) A person shall not be liable to be called up by virtue of this section unless, by virtue of the proclamations made under section one of the principal Act before he is called up, persons of his age and sex are liable to be called up.

(4) In this section references to discharge include references to cashiering, dismissal, removal, retirement and resignation.

5. After subsection (2) of section four of the National Service Act, 1941 (which relates to the enforcement of requirements as to medical examination) there shall be inserted the following subsections:—

• “ (2A) If any person, being a person who has made application for registration or who has at any time been provisionally registered, as a conscientious objector, has undergone or is undergoing a sentence of imprisonment for a term of three months or more imposed upon him for failing to comply with an order made under this section, then, if he claims that the offence was committed by reason of his conscientiously objecting to performing military service or combatant duties, he may apply in the prescribed manner to have his case considered by the appellate tribunal.

(2B) On any such application the appellate tribunal shall, if it finds that the offence for which the applicant was sentenced was committed by reason of such a conscientious objection as aforesaid, have power to make any order with respect to his registration as a conscientious objector which it would have had power to make on an appeal under section five of the principal Act, and any such order shall have effect immediately or upon his discharge from prison as the case may be.”

Supplemental.

6. Paragraph (d) of subsection (2) and subsection (4) of section one of the Emergency Powers (Defence) Act, 1939, as amended by subsection (2) of section one of the Emergency Powers (Defence) Act, 1940, shall have effect as if this Act had been passed before the commencement of the last mentioned Act.

7. Any expenses incurred by the Minister, a Secretary of State, or any other Minister of the Crown in consequence of the passing of this Act shall be paid out of moneys provided by Parliament.

8. — (1) In this Act—

" Defence Regulations " has the same meaning as in the Emergency Powers (Defence) Act, 1939;

“ liable to be called up” means liable to be called up for service under the principal Act or for civil defence under the National Service Act, 1941.

(2) References in this Act to any enactment shall, unless the context otherwise requires, be construed as references to that enactment as amended by or under any other enactment, including this Act.

9. This Act may be cited as the National Service (No. 2) Act, 1941, and shah be construed as one with the principal Act, and shall be included in the Acts which may be cited as the National Service Acts. 1939 to 1941.

SCHEDULE.

Women exempted from liability to be called up.

1. Members of Queen Alexandra’s Royal Naval Nursing Service or any reserve thereof.

2. Members of the Women’s Royal Naval Service.

3. Women medical practitioners serving in the Royal Navy or any naval reserve.

4. Members of Queen Alexandra's Imperial Military Nursing Service or any reserve thereof.

5. Members of the Territorial Army Nursing Service or any reserve thereof.

6. Members of the Auxiliary Territorial Service.

7. Women employed with the Royal Army Medical Corps or The Army Dental Corps with relative rank as officers.

8. Members of Princess Mary’s Royal Air Force Nursing Service or any reserve thereof.

9. Members of the Women’s Auxiliary Air Force.

10. Women employed with the Medical Branch or the Dental Branch of the Royal Air Force with relative rank as officers.

MEASURE

PASSED BY THE NATIONAL ASSEMBLY OF THE CHURCH OF ENGLAND WHICH RECEIVED THE ROYAL ASSENT DURING THE YEAR 1941.

4 & 5 Geo. 6.

No. 1.

A MEASURE passed by the National Assembly of the Church of England.

To provide for the appointment of Diocesan Reorganisation Committees and to define their powers and duties; to provide for deferring the restoration of damaged churches and parsonage houses, and for suspending the exercise of rights of presentation in certain cases; and to enable Diocesan Boards of Finance to receive payments under the War Damage Act, 1941.

[29th July 1941.]

1. As soon as may be after the passing of this Measure and in any case not later than six calendar months thereafter the Diocesan Conference of every diocese within the Provinces of Canterbury and York, except the Diocese of Sodor and Man, shall appoint a committee responsible to the Diocesan Conference to be known as the Diocesan Reorganisation Committee, constituted in accordance with the Schedule to this Measure.

2. It shall be the duty of the Diocesan Reorganisation Committee in each diocese— (i)

(i) to act on behalf of the owners of all church lands within the diocese with regard to—

(a) the presentation and negotiation of claims for compensation in respect of such lands under the War Damage Act, 1941, or any Act extending or amending the same;

2 F

Appointment of Diocesan Reorganisation Committees.

Duties of Diocesan Reorganisation Committees.

4 & 5 Geo 6.

c. 12

No. i.

ii

Diocesan Reorganisation Committees 4 & 5 G*o. 6.

Measure, 1941.

(6) the receipt by the Diocesan Board of Finance of any payments made by the War Damage Commission in respect thereof; and

(c) the disposal or allocation of any such payments, after consultation so far as practicable with the owners of the lands concerned, and subject to any conditions determined by the War Damage Commission;

(ii) to give advice to incumbents and others concerned as to the execution or deferment of repairs to churches and other buildings on church lands within the diocese;

(iii) to make recommendations to the bishop for rearrangement of the pastoral supervision of any area within the diocese in which by reason of war damage or other circumstances arising out of the war such rearrangement may appear to them to be desirable, after consultation so far as practicable with the incumbents, patrons and parochial church councils within such area, including recommendations for alterations of parochial boundaries, the holding of benefices in plurality, unions or disunions of benefices and parishes, the restoration or disposal of churches or parsonage houses or the sites thereof, the appropriation or re-allocation of endowments and any other matters consequential upon the proposed rearrangement.

Power to defer restoration of churches.

3. — (1) If the Diocesan Reorganisation Committee shall recommend that any church within the diocese injured by war damage shall not be restored pending further consideration, the bishop may request the Ecclesiastical Commissioners to make an order deferring the restoration of the church for a period not exceeding five years, and the Ecclesiastical Commissioners may thereupon make an order accordingly.

(2) The Ecclesiastical Commissioners shall send a copy of such order to the registrar of the diocese concerned to be filed in the diocesan registry, and shall send copies also to the incumbent and patron of the benefice and to the parochial church council of the parish in which the church is situate.

(3) While such order shall be in force the church shall not be restored without the consent of the bishop, and in the meantime—

(i) neither the parochial church council nor any other person shall be liable to maintain or insure the fabric of the church or any part thereof, including the chancel, except to such extent (if any) as may be provided by the order;

<^»ooQ[e

I941* Diocesan Reorganisation Committees No. I.

Measure, 1941.

(ii) any payment made in respect of insurance against war damage of the furniture and other chattels belonging to the church shall be received by the Diocesan Board of Finance, who shall repay thereout on application the amount of any premiums paid in respect thereof pursuant to the War Damage Act, 1941, and shall hold or apply the balance of such payment and any investments representing the same for the benefit of such church if restored, and otherwise for the benefit of such other church or churches as the Diocesan Reorganisation Committee shall determine, after consultation with the incumbent and parochial church council of the parish concerned;

(iii) banns of marriage of persons entitled to be married in the church may be published and marriages of such persons may be solemnised in such other church chapel or place of worship within the diocese as the bishop shall in writing direct.

(4) Any such order shall be reconsidered on the written request of the incumbent or patron of the benefice or parochial church council of the parish concerned.

4. — (1) If the Diocesan Reorganisation Committee shall recommend that any parsonage house within the diocese injured by war damage shall not be restored, the bishop may request Queen Anne's Bounty to make an order deferring the restoration of such house for a period not exceeding five years, and Queen Anne's Bounty may thereupon make an order accordingly.

(2) Queen Anne's Bounty shall send a copy of such order to the registrar of the diocese concerned to be filed in the diocesan registry, and shall send copies also to the incumbent and patron of the benefice, the parochial church council of the parish concerned, and the Diocesan Dilapidations Board.

(3) As from the date of such order, the incumbent shall cease to be liable to maintain the said parsonage house in accordance with the law of ecclesiastical dilapidations, unless and until the same shall have been restored, and Queen Anne's Bounty and the Diocesan Dilapidations Board shall make such consequential variations in any assessments or orders under the Ecclesiastical Dilapidations Measures 1923 to 1929 affecting such house and give such directions as to the repayment of any moneys paid under the said Measures and otherwise as the circumstances may from time to time require.

5. — (1) When the Ecclesiastical Commissioners have made an order under lection three of this Measure deferring the restoration of the principal church of any benefice, and the benefice is or

(i) the period between the making of the order or the

occurrence of the vacancy (whichever shall be the later) and the date when the consent of the bishop is given or the expiration of the said term of five years (whichever shall be the earlier) shall not be reckoned for purposes of lapse;

(2) Any question arising under this section as to which is the principal church of a benefice shall be determined by the bishop.

(3) This section shall not apply to rights of presentation vested in or exercised by His Majesty, whether in right of his Crown or of his Duchy of Lancaster, or to rights of presentation vested in or exercised by His Majesty or by the Duke of Cornwall as the possessor for the time being of the Duchy of Cornwall, or to rights of presentation exercised by the Admiralty in respect of benefices the patronage of which belongs to Greenwich Hospital.

6. The Diocesan Board of Finance of the diocese shall have power on behalf of the Diocesan Reorganisation Committee to give a receipt for moneys paid under section thirty-nine of the War Damage Act, 1941, in respect of church lands within the diocese, and shall hold or apply such moneys and any investments representing the same for such purposes as the Diocesan Reorganisation Committee shall direct.

7. In this Measure the following expressions have the following meanings respectively, that is to say—

“ the bishop” means the bishop of the diocese concerned;

“ church lands " includes all land as defined by the War Damage Act, 1941, within the Provinces of Canterbury and York which is held and used for ecclesiastical purposes of the Church of England or for the advancement of religion or religious education in accordance with the principles of the Church of England, except land belonging beneficially to cathedral or collegiate bodies or central or diocesan organisations;

“ Diocesan Dilapidations Board ” has the meaning assigned to it by the Ecclesiastical Dilapidations Measure, 1923;

the “ patron ” with reference to any benefice means the person or persons for the time being entitled otherwise than by lapse to present or collate to such benefice upon a vacancy;

" war damage " and “ War Damage Commission ” have the meanings assigned to them respectively by the War Damage Act, 1941.

8. This Measure may be cited as the Diocesan Reorganisation Short title.

SCHEDULE.

CONSTITUTION OF DIOCESAN REORGANISATION COMMITTEES.

1. The Diocesan Reorganisation Committee in every diocese shall consist of the following ex officio members, that is to say—

The bishop;

The suffragan bishops (if any);

The archdeacons;

and the following ordinary members, that is to say:—

Not less than ten or more than twenty other persons (of whom not less than one-third shall be of the clergy and not less than one-third shall be of the laity) elected or appointed by the Diocesan Conference or in such manner as the Diocesan Conference may direct, such persons not necessarily being members of the Diocesan Conference.

The Committee shall co-opt one person nominated by each of the following bodies which is not in the opinion of the Committee already adequately represented:—

the Diocesan Board of Finance;

the Diocesan Dilapidations Board;

the Diocesan Union of Benefices Committee (if any);

the Diocesan Advisory Committee for the care of churches;

the Diocesan Committee (if any) dealing with questions of

religious education.

2. The first ordinary members shall hold office until 1945. Thereafter ordinary members shall hold office for three years. The Committee shall have power to fill any casual vacancies and may act notwithstanding any vacancy in its membership.

3. The chairman of the Committee shall be the bishop or some other member of the Committee nominated by him.

2 G

No. i. Diocesan Reorganisation Committees 4 & 5 Geo. 6.

Measure, 1941.

4. Five members of the Committee shall form a quorum.

5. The Committee shall have power to appoint sub-committees, including persons not members of the Committee, to consider the problems of such areas as are referred to in paragraph (iii) of section two, or for other special purposes.

6. Subject to the foregoing provisions, and to any directions given by the Diocesan Conference, the Committee shah have power to regulate its own procedure.
